B
How is a proxy going to prevent MitM attacks? The question specifically asks for mutual authentication. That has to mean certificates on both the client and server. Answer B is the only mutual authentication answer listed.

Selected Answer: B
B for sure

comments.content: No. The "mutual authentication" described in this Wikipedia link is just based on knowing the password (or "secret"). Certificates are the answer here.

discussion.content:
Maybe: A. Utilize a challenge-response prompt as required input at username/password entry ?
From Wikipedia: "Mutual authentication is performed using a challenge–response handshake in both directions; the server ensures that the client knows the secret, and the client also ensures that the server knows the secret, which protects against a rogue server impersonating the real server. "
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Challenge%E2%80%93response_authentication#Simple_example_mutual_authentication_sequence
Please note: this seems to specifically address MITM attacks.
Also note: having "the client to use its own certificate during handshake" is not especially secure.

choices.D: Install a reverse proxy in the corporate DMZ configured to decrypt TLS sessions.

choices.B: Implement TLS and require the client to use its own certificate during handshake.

A company is not familiar with the risks associated with IPv6. The systems administrator wants to isolate IPv4 from IPv6 traffic between two different network segments. Which of the following should the company implement? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Disable network discovery protocol on all company routers.
choices.D: Disable the DHCPv6 service from all routers.
choices.C: Block IP protocol 41 using Layer 3 switches.
choices.E: Drop traffic for ::/0 at the edge firewall.
choices.A: Use an internal firewall to block UDP port 3544.

discussion.content:
Maybe:
D. Disable the DHCPv6 service from all routers. 
E. Drop traffic for ::/0 at the edge firewall. 

0.0.0.0/0 means source can be any IPv4 address
::/0 means source can be any IPv6 address
Therefore when you drop traffic for ::/0 at the edge firewall, all IPv6 is blocked.
If DHCPv6 is unconfigured because for example, Router Advertisements are used for configuring IPv6 hosts, then the service will fail to start
Right on the money with this one both answers are right. A is talking about Teredo.

comments.content:
This NetworkWorld article seems to suggest: that is not a good idea:
Can we block all IPv6 tunnels in our enterprise network?
Undesired/unexpected/hidden IPv6 tunnels should be blocke
"The other kind of tunnel is Teredo, which relies on UDP encapsulation. The default port used by Teredo is 3544. A naïve approach would be to use an ACL like access-list deny udp any any eq 3544 access-list deny udp any eq 3544 any But, the above ACL could block by mistake normal (non tunneled) packets that just happen to use port 3544. Moreover, a malicious user (or a trojanized host) can change the UDP from the default setting."
https://www.networkworld.com/article/2232349/can-we-block-all-ipv6-tunnels-in-our-enterprise-network-.html

This poster on the cisco forums seems to agree:
"In terms of blocking v6, native or tunneled, you can block ethertype 0x86dd to block native v6 packets. You'd probably also want your firewalls to block protocol 41 (IPv6 payload in an IPv4 envelope) and the default teredo server port 3544/udp. That will take out the main 3 automatic tunneling protocols for ISATAP, 6to4, and Teredo."
https://community.cisco.com/t5/ipv6/how-to-block-all-ipv6-in-3850/td-p/28527

questions.question_text:
The Chief Executive Officers (CEOs) from two different companies are discussing the highly sensitive prospect of merging their respective companies together.
Both have invited their Chief Information Officers (CIOs) to discern how they can securely and digitally communicate, and the following criteria are collectively determined:
✑ Must be encrypted on the email servers and clients
✑ Must be OK to transmit over unsecure Internet connections
Which of the following communication methods would be BEST to recommend?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I initially answered “D” but kept thinking this over and over, seeking that final resolution. Fortunately, I found it, on a legal website: https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/how-to-draft-a-letter-of-intent-loi-or-term-sheet.html.

If you scroll down to the “CONFIDENTIALITY” section, you’ll find this, “[…] ideally, before negotiating the LOI, you and the other party have already signed a confidentiality agreement covering all of the non-public information […]” and it goes on to say that you should use something like an NDA for that.

Keep in mind, LOI (letter-of-intent) is MOU, just a different way of saying it.

For me, that puts this one to bed. The answer is D, 100%. Please reference the above article.
